attributes.title: Comparing rates and characteristics of emergency department presentations related to pharmaceutical opioid poisoning in Australia: a study protocol for a retrospective observational study

q1.value: Comparing rates and characteristics of emergency department presentations related to pharmaceutical opioid poisoning in Australia: a study protocol for a retrospective observational study

q2.value: Tina Lam, Jane Hayman, Janneke Berecki-Gisolf, Paul Sanfilippo, Dan I Lubman, Suzanne Nielsen

q3.value: Pharmaceutical opioids are implicated in 70% of Australia’s opioid-related mortality, however, few studies have considered the relative contribution of individual pharmaceutical opioids to harm. We will identify pharmaceutical opioid poisonings from 2009-2019 using the Victorian Emergency Minimum Dataset (VEMD), which contains data from public hospital emergency departments (ED) in Victoria, Australia. We will calculate supply-adjusted rates of ED presentations for nine commonly prescribed pharmaceutical opioids. We will also compare demographic and clinical characteristics of these cases across opioids.

q4.value:
We will answer the following research questions:
1.	Do the supply-adjusted rates of ED presentations differ over time and across pharmaceutical opioids?
2.	Does the severity of presentation (as measured by triage category) or other characteristics vary by opioid type?

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Retrospective observational study that uses administrative emergency department data. 
Pharmaceutical opioid-poisoning related cases are identified, and coded for common opioids including fentanyl, buprenorphine, oxycodone, oxycodone-naloxone, codeine, morphine, methadone, tramadol and tapentadol (if information is available). Supply-adjusted rates are calculated to compare harms across opioids.

q9.value: No randomisation, this is a retrospective study/uses pre-exisiting administrative data.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: This study uses pre-existing emergency department administrative data from the Victorian Emergency Minimum Dataset (VEMD). Collaborators JH and JBG work for the Victorian Injury Surveillance Unit (VISU) which has access to the VEMD for routine surveillance of injuries within the state. No other collaborators have direct access to the VEMD. We have previously  examined the VEMD for trends on pharmaceutical opioid poisonings for an older time period, but have not adjusted these presentations by population or supply of opioid.

question.value: Data come from public hospital emergency department presentations. This population-wide study has a catchment area of the entire Victorian state, for the past 10 years (July 2009 – June 2019), for individuals aged 12 years of age and older.

q13.value: Based on past work with ED presentations for pharmaceutical-opioid poisonings, we anticipate a sample size of more than 5000.

q14.value: N/A – We will be capturing a population-level estimate - all public hospital ED attendances for pharmaceutical opioid poisoning available from the Victorian Emergency Minimum Dataset (VEMD).

q15.value: N/A – This is a retrospective observational study that uses administrative emergency department data.

question.value: N/A - This is a retrospective observational study that uses administrative emergency department data.

The primary outcome variable will be emergency department presentations for pharmaceutical opioid poisoning. These will be identified using a search using pharmaceutical opioid + poisoning related keywords and/or ICD10-AM poisoning diagnosis codes T40.2, T40.3, T40.4.



We will also examine patient demographics (age, sex, geographical region, country of birth, SEIFA [a proxy of SES based on postcode]) and presentation characteristics (human intent [e.g. unintentional, intentional self-harm], admission outcome, and triage severity). These variables are described in greater detail in the Victorian Emergency Department Dataset (VEMD) user manual: https://www2.health.vic.gov.au/about/publications/policiesandguidelines/vemd-manual-2019-20-sec-1-6
In calculating rates of presentations, if the numerator is less than 10 for the analysis period, we will aggregate the available data over multiple periods.

We will use Poisson regression to present Incident Rate Ratios with 95% CIs for supply adjusted rates of ED presentations. We will report on monthly (or longer time intervals to enable minimum cell sizes of five) rates of ED presentations, by individual pharmaceutical opioids.  We will use multinomial regression analysis to compare ED presentation characteristics associated with individual opioids. These characteristics include patient demographics, context of presentation, admission outcome, year, and triage severity of presentation.

q20.value: The ED presentation rates will be adjusted using the supply of the pharmaceutical opioid involved. Sales data will be used to estimate supply, and the total amount of each opioid supplied will be calculated in milligrams and converted to Oral Morphine Equivalents (OME).

q21.value: p values less than 0.05 will be considered significant.

q22.value: Every VEMD case will be manually checked by an experienced analyst to confirm it represents a pharmaceutical opioid poisoning.

q23.value: As a part of our ethics approval, we cannot report on any cell sizes less than 5, so we anticipate reported rates will aggregate data into multiple month blocks (e.g. 3-monthly periods).

q25.value:
1.	The study is funded by an untied educational grant from Seqirus. The funders will have no role in the study design, study conduct, analysis or data interpretation. Prior to publication, Seqirus will have the opportunity to review the manuscript and provide comment on factual inaccuracies, if identified.

2.	We have previously examined the emergency department presentations for pharmaceutical opioid poisonings for an earlier time period, but did not adjust the presentations by supply or population. The findings are reported in a technical report: https://www.monash.edu/__data/assets/pdf_file/0008/1981943/Hazard86_FINAL.pdf

q3.value:
We are conducting a manipulation check of a paragraph. 

Does reading about female gender inequality or discrimination against men on college campuses result in people perceiving that the issue was threatening to women or men, respectively?

q4.value: Reading a paragraph about female gender inequality or discrimination against men on college campuses will be perceived as more threatening to women or men, respectively, than reading a paragraph about gender equality on college campuses.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: Between subjects design with 1 factor (threat vs. no threat)

q9.value: We are estimating there will be approximately 50% female, 50% male. And within each of the females and males, we’ll have ½ randomly assigned to the threat condition and ½ randomly assigned to the no threat condition.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
We are recruiting 120 full-time college students through the online provider, Prolific, to participate in a 2-minute survey. 

Participants must be full-time college students in order to participate. They will be paid $0.30 for reading the paragraph & answer 1 question.

Participants are first asked their gender and then redirected to the “female” version of the survey or the “male” version of the survey. Within the female/male survey, they are randomly assigned to either the “high threat” or “no threat” condition.

The study timeline: survey launches March 6, 2020

q13.value: The sample size is 120 participants. We are estimating there will be approximately 50% female, 50% male. And within each of the females and males, we’ll have ½ randomly assigned to the threat condition and ½ randomly assigned to the no threat condition. So this will result in approximately 30 participants in each of the following cells: female/threat, female/no threat, male/threat, male/no threat.

q14.value: A power analysis was conducted. To achieve power of .8, the sample size required is 10 participants per cell. Because we will not for certain obtain 50% females, we increased this to approximately 30 participants per cell or a total of 120 participants.

q15.value: Data collection will terminate after 120 participants.

question.value:
We will manipulate identity threat. In the female condition, the high identity threat condition reads:

Despite efforts, gender equality – equal status between men and women – has not been achieved at universities.

Sexist behavior on college campuses continues to exist by both students and professors. Women continue to be discriminated against and treated with prejudice. For example, women are judged based on appearances rather than their accomplishments, and their achievements are not attributed to their abilities. In general, fellow students and professors pay more attention to men than women when they speak, and men often interrupt or talk over women or over-explain things to women as if women have no understanding of the issue. Women are also the target of sexist remarks and jokes. For example, women who take a leadership role or are assertive are called “too bossy”. In general, women are conceptualized as weak, delicate, incompetent, and therefore inferior to men.

In the male condition, the high identity threat condition reads:

In recent years, the discrimination against men has grown in universities.

Men are being discriminated against on college campuses. Colleges spend money supporting Women’s Studies programs and encouraging women to study STEM disciplines but no money is spent to support Men’s Studies programs or encourage men to study majors predominantly studied by women. In general, colleges create special scholarships for women and encourage employers to include female candidates when recruiting for jobs. Another example is the elimination of some of the most commonly played sports by men on college campuses as a result of Title IX. Men are also held to a different standard than women. For example, men are treated more harshly in campus disciplinary actions and are often denied rights provided to all Americans off campus. In general, men are at a disadvantage at universities.

For both the female and male condition, the no threat condition reads:

After years of effort, gender equality – equal status between men and women – has improved at universities.

There is an equal number of women and men enrolled on college campuses. Women and men are being supported equally on campus. For example, colleges spend money supporting programs for both women and men, and the number of women and men have become more similar within a range of majors and disciplines. Women and men are also treated more equally by both students and professors. For example, the achievements of both women and men are attributed to their abilities. In general, fellow students and professors pay equal attention to women and men when they speak. Employers include both female and male candidates when recruiting for jobs. In general, both men and women are viewed as competent, strong, and smart at universities.

We will measure the response to one question:

In the female condition:

Please indicate your agreement with the following (on a 7-point Likert scale, strongly disagree/strongly agree).
1.	The issue you read about was threatening to women.

In the male condition:

Please indicate your agreement with the following (on a 7-point Likert scale, strongly disagree/strongly agree).
2.	The issue you read about was threatening to men.
N/A

We will use one-way ANOVA to compare the threat/no threat cells within the female condition. We will use a separate one-way ANOVA to compare the threat/no threat cells within the male condition. 

The dependent variable in each ANOVA is the response to the question:

The issue you read about was threatening to women/men.

The independent variable is whether they were in the threat or no threat condition.

q21.value: We will consider the p-value of the ANOVA model described above to be significant if < .05, and marginal if < .10 but greater than equal to .05. We will use two tailed tests.

q23.value: Missing data will be specified as missing within SPSS. SPSS uses listwise deletion.

q3.value: This study aims to investigate the question of how the Big 5 Personality Traits (openness, conscientiousness, extraversion, agreeableness, and neuroticism) and self-esteem scores influence creativity. Specifically, the study purpose is to determine which personality traits are correlated with higher self-esteem scores, how personality and self-esteem impact creativity, and whether self-esteem acts as a moderator variable in the relationship between personality and creativity.

q4.value:
H1: Given previous research on the connection between self-esteem and personality, we expect a significant, positive correlation between certain personality traits and high self-esteem. Specifically, we expect to see individuals who score highly on constructs such extraversion and conscientiousness on the Big 5 Personality Inventory, and those who score somewhat high on agreeableness and openness, also scoring higher on the Rosenberg Self-Esteem scale. 

H2: We expect to see a significant, positive correlation between self-esteem and higher performance on creativity tasks. In other words, we expect that individuals who score higher on the Rosenberg Self-Esteem scale will report a higher percentage of correct answers on the Remote Associates test.

H3: We expect to see a significant, positive correlation between certain personality traits and better performance on the creativity task. In other words, we expect that individuals who score highly on personality constructs of openness and agreeableness on the Big 5 Personality Inventory will report a higher percentage of correct answers to the Remote Associates Test.

H4: Finally, when all three constructs are entered into a model, we propose that self-esteem will act as a moderating variable in the correlation between personality traits and creativity. Thus, the positive relationship between scores on the Big 5 Inventory traits and high performance on the Remote Associates Test can be explained by higher scores on the Rosenburg Self-Esteem scale.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: We will utilize a between subject, correlational design investigating the 3 factors of personality, self-esteem, and creativity. The predictor variables in this study are personality and self-esteem, the effect of which we will measure on the dependent variable of creativity. We will measure personality using the 44 question Big 5 Personality Inventory. We will measure self-esteem using the 10 question Rosenburg Self-Esteem scale. Finally, we will measure creativity using 15 questions from behavioral measure, Remote Associates Test.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: At least 40 undergraduates from Clemson University will participate in this study. Some participants outside of Clemson University may also be recruited for participation. Participants will be recruited through email, social media, or word of mouth. All of those involved will be 18 years or older. The study is completed online through Qualtrics.

q13.value: We collect response from a minimum of 40 participants and a maximum of 100 participants in this sample.

q14.value: We used the software program G*Power 3.1 to conduct a power analysis. Our goal was to obtain .80 power to detect a medium effect size of .15 at the standard .05 alpha error probability. To do this, we would need at least 98 participants.

q15.value:
We will plan to collect data for three weeks (from 3/5/2020 – 3/25/2020). 
We will stop data collection at the end of that three week period.

question.value: None

Our outcome variable/dependent variable in this study is creativity, measured using 15 questions from the Remote Associates Test.

Our predictor variables in this study are personality, measured from 44 questions on Big 5 Inventory, and self-esteem, measured from 10 questions on the Rosenburg Self-Esteem scale.

We are not controlling for any covariates.

To investigate the overall interaction of both predictor variables (personality and self-esteem) on creativity, we will use a regression analysis. 

Within our predictor variables, we will conduct a correlation analysis between openness scores and self-esteem, conscientiousness scores and self-esteem scores, agreeableness scores and self-esteem, extraversion scores and self-esteem, and neuroticism scores and self-esteem.

We will also conduct correlation analysis to determine the relationship between self-esteem scores and creativity.

q22.value: We will exclude anyone who does not pass the awareness check included in the Big 5 Inventory (additive question asking participant to choose a particular answer). We will also exclude any participants who do not provide a single answer to any of the Remote Associates Test and who do not type in "N/A" to those questions they do not complete.

q23.value: We will exclude participants who give incomplete or missing data. For responses to the Remote Associates Task, participants who provide at least one response to the task will be included in the analysis. Those who respond "N/A" to all of the questions to indicate that they read instructions and gave effort, but could not complete the task, will also be included.

registration_responses.q3: This study aims to investigate the question of how the Big 5 Personality Traits (openness, conscientiousness, extraversion, agreeableness, and neuroticism) and self-esteem scores influence creativity. Specifically, the study purpose is to determine which personality traits are correlated with higher self-esteem scores, how personality and self-esteem impact creativity, and whether self-esteem acts as a moderator variable in the relationship between personality and creativity.

H1: Given previous research on the connection between self-esteem and personality, we expect a significant, positive correlation between certain personality traits and high self-esteem. Specifically, we expect to see individuals who score highly on constructs such extraversion and conscientiousness on the Big 5 Personality Inventory, and those who score somewhat high on agreeableness and openness, also scoring higher on the Rosenberg Self-Esteem scale. 

H2: We expect to see a significant, positive correlation between self-esteem and higher performance on creativity tasks. In other words, we expect that individuals who score higher on the Rosenberg Self-Esteem scale will report a higher percentage of correct answers on the Remote Associates test.

H3: We expect to see a significant, positive correlation between certain personality traits and better performance on the creativity task. In other words, we expect that individuals who score highly on personality constructs of openness and agreeableness on the Big 5 Personality Inventory will report a higher percentage of correct answers to the Remote Associates Test.

H4: Finally, when all three constructs are entered into a model, we propose that self-esteem will act as a moderating variable in the correlation between personality traits and creativity. Thus, the positive relationship between scores on the Big 5 Inventory traits and high performance on the Remote Associates Test can be explained by higher scores on the Rosenburg Self-Esteem scale.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.

attributes.title: Rapid Review of Supportive Care in COVID 19

q1.value: Rapid review of the Availability, Quality and Inclusivity of Supportive Care Guidelines in COVID 19

q3.value: In 2019 an epidemic of  novel coronavirus spread from its origin in China across the globe. There are no known interventions which affect the course of the disease and as such treatment is supportive. This rapid review seeks to examine the availability, quality and inclusivity of supportive care guidelines in treating novel coronavirus disease Covid 19.

q4.value: Optimal supportive care is the primary treatment for Covid 19. However, the disease is new and as such there is little scientific literature to inform treatment. It is suggested that many of the guidelines in this area will be written using indirect evidence in a non-systematic manner. We can test the quality of written guidelines using accepted tools such as the AGREE II tool.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Design Plan

5.	Study type 
5.1.	Rapid Review 

6.	Blinding 
6.1.	No blinding is involved in this study.

7.	Study design
7.1.	This study will be a rapid review of established supportive care guidelines.
7.2.	For this review we have produced a rigorous search of the published literature detailed in the next section.
7.3.	In order to facilitate rapid review of the literature, each reference will be single-screened according to predetermined screening strategy. 
7.4.	Each guideline that passed initial eligibility screening will be entered for detailed analysis of:
7.4.1.	Availability - is the guideline available open-source or hidden behind firewalls?
7.4.2.	Inclusivity - which groups are covered by the guidelines? Were vulnerable groups such as pregnant women, children included?
7.4.3.	Quality - assessment of quality using the AGREE II Tool.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value:
8.	Existing data (required)

8.1.1.	A systematic review has been performed according to the following strategy.
8.1.2.	The following databases were searched from inception to search date (06/02/2020) for relevant studies: Ovid Medline; Ovid Embase; Ovid Global Health; Scopus; Web of Science Core Collection; WHO Global Index Medicus. The search strategies applied the CADTH database guidelines search filter [Strings attached: CADTH database search filters [Internet]. Ottawa: CADTH; 2016. [cited 06/02/2020]. Available from: https://www.cadth.ca/resources/finding-evidence/strings-attached-cadths-database-search-filters#guide *full reference*] to text words and relevant index terms for each of the three Clusters. No limits were applied to the search results. The full search strategies will be listed in the the appendix. Further studies were identified through searches constructed for Google Scholar, and recommendation by a panel of experts.
8.1.3.	At the date of pre-registration data extraction had not commenced.
8.1.4.	No analysis has been conducted related to the research plan (including calculation of summary statistics). 

9.	Explanation of existing data 
9.1.	This rapid review utilizes search data from a broader systematic review that had been planned before the Coronavirus epidemic in 2019.
9.2.	The rapid review will differ from that systematic review in that sources will be single screened by reviewers to facilitate more expeditious results.

question.value:
10.	Data collection procedures
10.1.	The data in this study are guidelines looking at Supportive Care in Coronavirus. This data is largely published by national and international bodies suchas the WHO.

11.	Measured variables
11.1.	There are three main variables:
11.1.1.	Availability: It is important to ascertain whether guidelines on the treatment of Novel Coronavirus are obscured behind firewalls, require journal subscription etc.
11.1.2.	Inclusivity: We wish to determine whether guidelines are available for a range of groups including pregnant women, children etc.
11.1.3.	Quality: We wish to ascertain whether supportive care guidelines have been produced in a rigorous, systematic manner. We will utilise the widely available AGREE II tool.

12.	Data exclusion 
12.1.	A single screener will decide the relevance of a source based on a predetermined search strategy.
12.2.	A subset of excluded data will be analysed to confirm the rigor of this screening strategy

registration_responses.q1: Rapid review of the Availability, Quality and Inclusivity of Supportive Care Guidelines in COVID 19
registration_responses.q3: In 2019 an epidemic of  novel coronavirus spread from its origin in China across the globe. There are no known interventions which affect the course of the disease and as such treatment is supportive. This rapid review seeks to examine the availability, quality and inclusivity of supportive care guidelines in treating novel coronavirus disease Covid 19.
registration_responses.q4: Optimal supportive care is the primary treatment for Covid 19. However, the disease is new and as such there is little scientific literature to inform treatment. It is suggested that many of the guidelines in this area will be written using indirect evidence in a non-systematic manner. We can test the quality of written guidelines using accepted tools such as the AGREE II tool.
registration_responses.q5: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.

attributes.title: Caffeine, Sleep, and Feelings and Dispositions

q1.value: Sleep, Caffeine, and Feelings and Dispositions

q3.value: The purpose of this study is to determine the impact of sleep and caffeine consumption on mood. The impact of sleep and caffeine consumption on mood will be measured by the Positive and Negative Affect Schedule. Sleep will be assessed through participants’ recording of the number of hours slept the previous night. Caffeine will be measured through the number of 8-ounce beverages consumed within 6-hour intervals.

q4.value: Higher caffeine consumption will be associated with positive mood. Fewer hours of sleep will be associated with negative mood. Lower caffeine consumption and fewer hours of sleep will have a negative impact on mood.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The dependent variable is mood. Mood will be measured using the Positive and Negative Affect Mood Schedule. The independent variables are the amount of hours of sleep that someone gets the night before and how many 8 oz beverages, containing caffeine, are consumed in six hour intervals. This is a correlational design.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: 40 undergraduates from Clemson University will participate in this study. Participants will be recruited through email and social media. All of those involved will be 18 years or older. The study is online through Qualtrics.

q14.value: We used the software program G*Power 3.1 to conduct a power analysis. Our goal was to obtain .80 power to detect a medium effect size of .15 at the standard .05 alpha error probability. To do this, we'd need at least 68 participants.

q15.value:
We will plan to collect data for 3 weeks (from 3/5/2020 - 3/25/2020).
We will stop data collection at the end of that 3 week period.

question.value: None.

The dependent variable is mood. The independent variables are the amount of hours of sleep the individual gets the night before and the amount of 8 oz. caffeinated drinks the individual consumes in six hour intervals.

This study looks at the correlation between caffeine consumption and mood and also between amount of sleep and mood. Then a regression will be run to observe the relationship  between caffeine consumption and amount of sleep on mood.

q3.value: The purpose of this study is to determine the relationship between social media, gender and self-esteem.

q4.value: We predict that there will be a positive association between social media usage and self-esteem.  Additionally, we predict that there will be an interaction between gender and social media usage on self-esteem such that there will be a positive association between time spent on social media and self-esteem for females but not for males.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: We are using a correlational design with social media usage as an independent variable, gender being a quasi-independent variable, and self-esteem being the dependent variable. To measure self-esteem we are using the Rosenberg Self Esteem scale. In our survey, we are using a fill in the blank question to collect participant's gender. The following questions will be used create a composite score to measure social media usage: The amount of likes on my tweets increase my self-esteem, The amount of likes on my Instagram picture increases my self-esteem,  Celebrities, models, and/or popular figures may cause someone to believe that being skinny is the same as being pretty, Social media boosts my self-confidence, The number of followers I have affect my use of the site, When I lose followers, I feel a decrease in a self-esteem,  I use social media to connect with old and/or new friends, The number of followers I have is important to me,  My social media outlets accurately reflect who I am, I am more comfortable with myself on social media than I am in real life,  The attention I get from posting on social media makes me feel good,  I feel jealous when I see the lives of others, I feel others are more successful than I am, I post pictures for others' reactions, I could go a week without using social media, I only post the best version of myself.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: At least 40 undergraduates from Clemson University will participate in this study. Participants will be recruited through email, social media, or word of mouth. All of those involved will be 18 years or older. The study is online through Qualtrics

q14.value: We used the software program G*Power 3.1 to conduct a power analysis. Our goal was to obtain .80 power to detect a medium effect size of .15 at the standard of .05 alpha error probability. To do this, we'd need at least 68 participants.

q15.value: We will plan to collect data for 3 weeks (03/05/2020-3/25/2020). We will stop data collection at the end of that 3 week period.

question.value: None
Our dependent variable is self-esteem. The independent variable is social media usage and the quasi-independent variable is gender. We have no covariates.

A correlation will be done to examine the relationship between social media usage on self-esteem. A t-test will be done to examine the effect of gender on self-esteem. Finally a regression will be used to measure the interaction between social media usage and gender on self-esteem.

q22.value: Exclude any data from participants who are not in the age range from 18- 25.

attributes.title: Relationships of Biological Sex, Gender Roles, and Social Desirability
attributes.description:
The study will examine the relationship between biological sex, gender roles, and concern for social
desirability. We hypothesize that high scores in femininity and high scores in masculinity will
positively correlate to high scores in concern for social desirability.

q1.value: Relationships of Biological Sex, Gender Roles, and Concern for Social Desirability

q3.value: The study will examine the relationships between biological sex, gender roles, and concern for social desirability.

q4.value: We hypothesize that high scores in femininity and high scores in masculinity will positively correlate with high scores in concern for social desirability. We hypothesize that female biological sex will predict high scores in femininity and that male biological sex will predict high scores in masculinity. We expect that biological females that score high in femininity and biological males that score high in masculinity will not have statistically different concern for social desirability.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This study has a correlational design. The predictor variables are biological sex and gender role score, and the outcome variable is concern for social desirability score. Biological sex will be a categorical variable that will be measured using an open-ended question. Gender role scores will be a continuous variable that is measured using the Bem Sex Role Inventory. Concern for social desirability scores will be a continuous variable that is measured using the Marlowe-Crowne Social Desirability Scale.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: At least 40 undergraduates from Clemson University will participate in this study. Participants will be recruited through email, social media, or word of mouth. All of those involved will be 18 years or older. The study is online through Qualtrics.

q13.value: The sample size will be between 40 and 100 participants.

q14.value: We used the software program G*Power 3.1 to conduct a power analysis. Our goal was to obtain .80 power to detect a medium effect size of .15 at the standard .05 alpha error probability. To do this, we'd need at least 68 participants.

q15.value: We will plan to collect data for 3 weeks (from 3/5/2020- 3/25/2020). We will stop data collection at the end of that 3 week period.

question.value: There will be no manipulated variables.

Biological sex will be a categorical variable that will be measured using an open-ended question. Gender role scores will be a continuous variable that is measured using the Bem Sex Role Inventory. Social desirability scores will be a continuous variable that is measured using the Marlowe-Crowne Social Desirability Scale. This score quantifies the degree to which an individual is concerned for social desirability.

We will use regressions to analyze all three variables (biological sex, gender role score, and concern for social desirability score). We will use a correlation to analyze gender role score and concern for social desirability. We will use independent samples t-test between biological sex and gender role score and between biological sex and social desirability score.

q20.value: Biological sex will be coded as 1.00 for female and 2.00 for male, and any other responses will be coded as 3.00.

q22.value: We put in one question that asks the participant to select the "neutral" response. If they do not select that option, their data will be excluded.

q1.value: The Science of Influence: How College Student’s Self-Esteem affects their perception of Influencer-Branded Content on Social Media

q3.value: The study will assess factors that contribute to how college students view Instagram influencers as reliable sources of information. We will be examining how effective an influencer can be at marketing products to their followers. This will be correlated to the level of self-esteem in the study’s participants.

q4.value: Directional Hypothesis: We predict that lower levels of self esteem will be negatively correlated with willingness to trust social media influencers. Participants who have lower scores on the Rosenburg Self Esteem Scale will be more easily influenced. We predict an interaction in which participants who have low self esteem and view the Influencer as reliable would be more likely to trust an influencer.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
This is a correlational study. The variables being measured are participant’s self-esteem and their perception of social media influencers’ trustworthiness. We have decided on three variables that could contribute to an influencer’s status: physical attractiveness, likeability, and relatability. We will also be looking to find a relationship between these variables and an influencer’s perceived trustworthiness.

We will be measuring self-esteem through the Rosenberg Self Esteem Scale. 

Physical Attractiveness will be defined using the definition proposed by Morrow (1990) - “the degree to which one's facial image elicits favorable reaction from another.” 

Likeability will be defined similarly to the concept of “warmth” as defined by Fisk, Cuddy, & Glick (2007). In our experiment, Likeability encompasses traits such as perceived friendliness, sociability, kindness, and charisma. 

Relatability will be defined as how similar a person perceives an influencer to be to themself. It will also be defined as to how accessible and open the person seems to be. 

We will be defining trustworthiness as the extent to which a person is willing to take statements from an influencer as reliable, factual, and informative. 

We will be asking participants to take a Qualtrics survey. The survey will be split into three parts: The Rosenberg Self Esteem Scale, Open-Ended Questions, and Closed Ended Questions. The Closed-Ended Questions will be asking participants the extent to which they agree or disagree with statements using a Likhert scale. All of the responses will be anonymous.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: At least 40 undergraduates from Clemson University will participate in this study. Participants will be recruited through email, social media, or word of mouth. All of these participants will be 18 years or older. The study is online through Qualtrics.

q13.value: The sample size of our study will be at least 40 - 100 undergraduate students

q14.value: We used the software program G*Power 3.1 to conduct a power analysis. Our goal was to obtain a .80 power to detect a medium effect size of .15 at the standard .05 alpha error probability. To do this, we'd need at least 68 participants.

q15.value: We will plan to collect data for 3 weeks from (3/5/20-3/25/20). We will stop data collection at the end of that 3 week period.

question.value: NONE

We will be measuring self-esteem through the Rosenberg Self Esteem Scale. (Predictor Variable) 

Physical Attractiveness will be defined using the definition proposed by Morrow (1990) - “the degree to which one's facial image elicits favorable reaction from another.” (Predictor Variable)

Likeability will be defined similarly to the concept of “warmth” as defined by Fisk, Cuddy, & Glick (2007). In our experiment, Likeability encompasses traits such as perceived friendliness, sociability, kindness, and charisma. (Predictor Variable) 

Relatability will be defined as how similar a person perceives an influencer to be to themself. It will also be defined as to how accessible and open the person seems to be. (Predictor Variable) 

We will be defining trustworthiness as the extent to which a person is willing to take statements from an influencer as reliable, factual, and informative. (Dependent Variable)
NONE

We will be correlating participants' self esteem with their perception of social media influencers' trustworthiness. We will conduct a regression to look at the relationship between social media factors and self esteem impacting trustworthiness.

Physical Attractiveness will be defined using the definition proposed by Morrow (1990) - “the degree to which one's facial image elicits favorable reaction from another.” (Predictor Variable)

Likeability will be defined similarly to the concept of “warmth” as defined by Fisk, Cuddy, & Glick (2007). In our experiment, Likeability encompasses traits such as perceived friendliness, sociability, kindness, and charisma. (Predictor Variable) 

Relatability will be defined as how similar a person perceives an influencer to be to themself. It will also be defined as to how accessible and open the person seems to be. (Predictor Variable) 

We will be defining trustworthiness as the extent to which a person is willing to take statements from an influencer as reliable, factual, and informative. (Dependent Variable)
registration_responses.q18.question: NONE
registration_responses.q19.question: We will be correlating participants' self esteem with their perception of social media influencers' trustworthiness. We will conduct a regression to look at the relationship between social media factors and self esteem impacting trustworthiness.

attributes.title: The Effect of Sports Team Identification on Self-Efficacy

q1.value: The Relationship Between Sports Team Identification and Self-Efficacy

q3.value: The goal of this study is to examine the success of a fan's sports team and their identification with the team, as it relates to personal self-efficacy. We will use convenience sampling to have participants take a survey to see the correlation between identification with team and self-efficacy.

q4.value:
We predict a positive correlation between sports team identification and self-efficacy.
We also predict a positive correlation between sports team success and self-efficacy.
We also predict an interaction such that those with both high sports team identification and with a high level of success within in their team will predict self-efficacy.  Specifically, positive relationship between a high level of identification with a successful team and a high level self-efficacy.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Correlational Study

Quasi-Independent Variables:
- Personal identification with sports team
- Sports team success

Dependent Variable:
- Self-Efficacy

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
At least 40 undergraduates from Clemson University will participate in this study. Participants will be recruited through email, social media, or word of mouth. All of those involved will be 18 years or older.
The study is online through Qualtrics.

q14.value: We used the software program G*Power 3.1 to conduct a power analysis. Our goal was to obtain .80 power to detect a medium effect size of .15 at the standard .05 alpha error probability. To do this, we'd need at least 68 participants.

q15.value: We will plan to collect data for 3 weeks (from 3/5/20 - 3/25/20). We will stop data collection at the end of that 3 week period.

question.value: None

Dependent Variable: Self-Efficacy (measured using the New General Self-Efficacy Scale)
Quasi-Independent Variables:
- Sports Team Identification (measured using the Sport Spectator Identification Scale)
- Sports Team Success (measured by a yes/no question regarding team playoff appearances)
Covariates: N/A

We will use a Correlation Test to examine the correlation between Sports Team Identification and Self-Efficacy.
We will use a Correlation Test to examine the correlation between Sports Team Success and Self-Efficacy.
We will use a Multiple Regression Analysis to examine the relationship between our quasi-independent variables (Sports Team Identification and Sports Team Success) with our dependent variable (Self-Efficacy).

attributes.title: The Role of Parental Status and How it Affects Stress in Adult Life

q1.value: The Role of Parental Status and How it Affects Stress in Adult Life

q3.value: The purpose of this study is to determine if trust,  depression, and parental status (environment people grew up in) predict stress levels.

q4.value:
1) Among those that come from married families, there will be a negative correlation with stress. 
2) Those who have higher depression will have a negative correlation with stress. 3) Those who have lower trust will have a positive correlation with stress. 
4) We predict an interaction such that, those who have higher depression and lower trust will have a positive correlation with stress.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: We will be using a correlational design for our study and using a survey to gather our data. To gather our data we will be sending out emails which include an Qualtrics url to Clemson University students ranging in ages between 18 to 25. This url will have questions coming from the General Trust Scale, Center for Epidemiological Studies Depression Scale, Perceived Stress Scale-10 Scale, and indictions of what type of parental status you grew up with in order for us to obtain data on trust and depression as well as stress.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: At least 100 undergraduate students from Clemson University will participate in this study. Participants will be recruited through email or text messaging. All of those involved will be 18-25 years old. Data will obtained through Qualtrics link.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 100 participants and attempt to recruit up to 130.

q14.value: We used the software program G*Power to conduct a power analysis. Our goal was to obtain .80 power to detect a medium effect size of .15 at the standard .05 alpha error probability. To do this. we'd need at least 77 participants.

q15.value: We will plan to collect data for 3 weeks (from 3/5/2020 - 3/25/2020). We will stop data at the end of that 3 week period.

question.value: None.

The Independent Variables include trust, depression, and the interaction between trust and depression, along with the Quasi-Independent Variable being parental status which is defined as the environment people grew up in. We will measure trust by using the General Trust Scale and measure depression by using the Center for Epidemiological Studies Depression Scale. The Quasi-Independent Variable in our study will be measured by defining your parents marital status as married, divorced, widowed, single-parent, other (with specification), or prefer not to say. Lastly, the Dependent Variable in our study is stress. We will measure stress by using the Perceived Stress Scale-10 Scale.

We will use a correlation measure for both of our predictors along with our interaction to analyze our results. We will use correlation measures through hypothesis 1-3 and then use regression for hypothesis 4.
